I think the problem here is, much like if I were talking about male body types and only brought up pro boxers or MMA fighters, that they are only picking from a certain subset of "strong women" (ie. strike-based fighters and grapplers that try to fit within a certain weight range since it determines who they will be fighting). 

Just doing a quick Google search, there are also women like Aja Kong and Miki Satoyama that compete with their strength, just like how there are guys like Brian Shaw and Manny Pacquiao--two very different dudes, but I can't really think of anyone who wouldn't consider them both to be strong. In Street Fighter, you've got guys like E. Honda and Vega and Birdie and Dhalsim duking it out--all very different guys! (Although unfortunately, the female end of the roster has a much more limited range, and even more unfortunately, this isn't really something out of the ordinary--aside from a monster or two, even League's roster suffers from this)

Although, Vi to me seems like she'd fit more easily into someone like Samantha Wright's bodytype. Tough and compact, like a fist (and undoubtedly strong enough to lift up those gauntlets and hurt people with them), which could also be a fun juxtaposition with Caitlyn's more tall and narrow silhouette. I'm not going to harp on too much about Vi since what's done is done and Riot's artistic vision has certainly brought them a degree of success (and it's possible that I'm just looking at things the wrong way), but it kinda says something to me that Vi and Quinn have the same base body, yet the latter still reads 100% as a lithe and agile scout. You can't really do the same thing with Braum and TF, for instance!

You folks are getting a bit better about keeping the guys and gals of League on somewhat even ground (Illaoi is a nice contrast to the rest of the female roster, even if she doesn't immediately make it as varied and interesting as the male side), so I've got a good amount of faith that we'll be seeing some interesting and divergent silhouettes in the future. Variety is the spice of life, and all!

I'm not even going to blame Riot on this one, I honestly doubt they designed her with "Let's totally make her look weak" in mind. It's just that what Vi is, is "default," and it's the same pretty much everywhere else in the industry. In Street Fighter, you've got fighters ranging from Zangief to Vega to Birdie to Ken, but among, say, Cammy/Chun Li/R. Mika/Karin/Laura, there's still some variance (Chun Li's thighs dwarf Karin's, Laura's wearing a belt, R. Mika's parents are alive), but not nearly as much as the male end of the roster. Hell, even looking at Overwatch, you've got a dwarf and a huge armored knight and a guy with a pig belly, but the ladies range from "hourglass sexy" to "not as hourglass sexy" to "Zarya" etc. (This kind of stuff is why rosters like Indivisble's get me so hype--I'm always a fan of over-the-top and stylized silhouettes, but it always leaves a bad taste in my mouth when that sort of treatment is as one-sided as it tends to be)

But back to the point! Vi's a champion from an era (hopefully) long past, where champions like Leona and Syndra and Lux and Riven didn't vary as much as Garen and Ezreal and Braum and Lee Sin, despite representing wildly different archetypes and fantasies. It's a shame that Vi and Caitlyn aren't as juxtaposed physically as they are in just about every other way, but hopefully Illaoi is the start of Riot getting a bit more comfortable and branching out from the default more readily when it comes to lady champions (and not making the common mistake of seeing their gender as a factor that limits design choices). I look forward to the day where we can have gals as jolly as Gragas, as crooked as Swain, and as torn-the-hell-up as the new Gangplank. Shit'll be cool, man, so it better happen!

A few things:

-Even if she isn't lifting the power fists with her arms due to the assistance of the device on her back (which, looking at her in-game model, doesn't seem to be directly connected to the gauntlets, and in-game only seems to generate she shield from her passive), she'd still have to carry the weight of the fists AND the device with the rest of her body. In that case, she'd have the built core and legs of a professional weightlifter, but that's also not the case. 

-Even if it's artistic license, or somebody at Riot came onto the forums tomorrow and explained that Vi is actually the physically weakest champion and she's lifting the gauntlets because of magic because they said so, that brings forth an even more important question--why? Why does a character who is meant to be rugged, who is defined by her rough demeanor and preference for brute force, have the same base model as Quinn, who is the opposite of those things? Braum is big and broad-shouldered, has muscles to spare, and carries around a huge metal door/shield because he is characterized by his strength and durability. Twisted Fate is slim and lean and wiry because he relies more on his wits than his fists, and isn't built like a brick house because that would only slow him down. Gragas is vast and jolly and beer-bellied because he's the ultimate boozed-up bruiser, he has his weight and knows how to throw it around (and he still needs to be able to carry and throw around that big cask, too). 

I can make up any number of excuses as to why Vi doesn't embody her character as much as she could, why her whole archetype falls flat the moment you take away her gloves (you can take away Garen's sword, he's still a goddamn linebacker), but that's pointless. It's okay to like things despite (or even because of) their flaws. I still think Vi is a really cool character, she was my favorite for over a year. It is important, though, to realize and accept shortcomings, rather than excuse them.

Now if there is ever a lore event where Riot decides to give Vi an updated body definition after using the gloves for so long then I don't mind that, but to say that Riot didn't do Vi justice by making her "thin" gives me the impression that you might've missed the point. There's a principle in character design, where creating the strongest impact comes from absolute unity or absolute juxtaposition. Let's take two of League's characters as examples: Garen is meant to portray a strong character--this is done by giving him a sturdy build, bulky armor, and a massive sword; the updated Poppy is also meant to portray a strong character--which, in this case, is done by juxtaposing her small frame with her massive weapon.

These are two very different characters, and they portray two very different ideas of "strength"--Garen is a mighty juggernaut, while Poppy is a determined little Yordle-who-could. Every aspect of a character's design is the result of a tool being used, and each tool has their consequence. A character with unity is something because of what they are, a character with juxtaposition is something despite of what they are.

At first glance, it might seem that a lot of people in this thread are going "It's okay for Vi to have the same delicate wimp arms as Sona, it juxtaposes with her massive gauntlets and really brings to light how vulnerable she is without them!" and that would be entirely true, if the core of Vi's character was that she was innately vulnerable and was nothing without those gauntlets, like if you [took the Philosopher's Stone away from Envy](http://vignette4.wikia.nocookie.net/fma/images/f/f9/True-forms.png/revision/latest?cb=20140104182234) (which was an element used to juxtapose them with the protagonists, who seemingly lost everything, but whose innate qualities allowed them to build themselves back up again every time), then this would all make sense. In Vi's case, however, her gauntlets are an extension of her strength rather than the source of them, which could be evidenced in their inception--she saw people in trouble, she wrenched those suckers off of some robot, and then she proceeded to punch the shit out of some rubble. Even before that, [she was characterized by being rough, tough, and self-sufficient](http://leagueoflegends.wikia.com/wiki/Vi/Background)--she was all of these things before the gauntlets, and that's why she has them in the first place.

If the argument here is that Vi should not appear strong (and she doesn't have to be an obelisk like Illaoi--a compact build similar to Samantha Wright's would probably suit what she does better and could also juxtapose nicely with Cait's tall-and-narrow silhouette), then I'd say it would be wildly inaccurate to her character, it would be a cue that sends all the wrong messages--messages such as "she's not so tough without the gloves" or "her core character trait is vulnerability" and so on.

Going to the Cloud example, I'm going to borrow from professional wrestling with the concept of a "sell"--usually when a move wants to be portrayed as powerful, both wrestlers will have to "sell" it to the crowd. The wrestler performing the move should look like they're giving their all, while the wrestler receiving it should look like they're getting thrown by a much more powerful force than the first wrestler is exerting. Like with Cloud, you can look at him swing the sword around as if it were weightless, but that doesn't sell the weight of the sword or Cloud's strength, it only makes the sword look really, really light (and the Final Fantasy series as a whole tends to not have a great track record when it comes to a lot of their character designs, as iconic as they may be). Someone like [Guts](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=QIA9xg2oIew&feature=youtu.be), on the other hand, is clearly physically strong, and is sword is massive, but he still shows exertion when he swings it and the wind-up/wind-down is often exaggerated, which serves to "sell" both how strong Guts is and how heavy his sword is (Ike from the most recent iteration of Smash Bros. is another good example of this, especially since now you can see him side-by-side with Cloud). Of course, none of this means that Cloud is a horrible character design, but it does mean that looking at him side-by-side with, say, Sabin or Azul, it would be very easy to say that they are (or seem to be) more capable of feats of strength than him. I'd flinch much more easily at one of Lee Sin's punches than those from the Vi in this teaser if she's not wearing those big ol' gloves, and that kind of sucks. 

Winding back up to the "Illaoi can't be a femme fatale" and stuff like that, I'm not saying she can't be charming because of her build (in fact, a lot of her unique charm comes from that build), but if you wanted a character who reads as a sly and coy master of manipulation, you'd go for someone like Miss Fortune or LeBlanc, not Illaoi (who would seem more likely to manipulate you with her physical strength and overpowering personality--and every time we see her in the story, that's exactly what she does!).

Anyway, long story short, Vi could make sense as a character with wimp arms like Sona's, but that would require her to be a completely different character than what has been shown to us so far, and that her physique is much more likely a result of the weird self-imposed and habitual limitations a lot of people put on female characters (hence why a lot of them look the same aside from recent outliers like Illaoi), rather than an intentional design decision to use it as a meaningful character cue.

With Braum and Trynd, you have a train of thought: you look at them, and go "oh, they're strong" -> "they are physically substantial" -> "they partake in a lot of physical activity" -> "they may be able to survive in the tundra because of their physical might/endurance, constant physical activity, or a more abstract inner heat (hotbloodedness in Trynd's case, warm-heartedness is Braum's case)". Again, this is why it wouldn't make sense if TF was out there in pool shorts and little else.
